case_vignette: A 34-YEAR-OLD HEALTHY FEMALE PRESENTS FOR EVALUATION OF A BUMP ON HER LEFT THIRD FINGER PRESENT OVER THE PAST NINE MONTHS. SHE DENIES ANY TRAUMA TO THE AREA AND FIRST NOTICED IT WHEN GETTING A MANICURE. THE SPOT BEGAN AS A SMALL BUMP THAT PROGRESSIVELY ENLARGENED WITH ASSOCIATED DEPRESSION OF THE FINGERNAIL. PHYSICAL EXAMINATION OF THE LEFT THIRD FINGER REVEALS A TRANSLUCENT NODULE ALONG THE PROXIMAL NAIL FOLD WITH ASSOCIATED LONGITUDINAL DEPRESSION OF THE NAIL PLATE.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a bump on my left third finger that has been growing for nine months, and my fingernail is also dipping inwards.
Has the bump changed in color or caused any pain?
No, the bump has not changed in color and it doesn't cause any pain.
Do you have a history of similar bumps on your fingers or toes, or have any family members had similar issues?
No, I don't have a history of similar bumps, and as far as I know, no family members have had similar issues.
Are you currently taking any medications or have you had any recent injuries to your finger?
No, I am not taking any medications and I haven't had any recent injuries to my finger.
Is the skin around the bump normal or has it changed in texture or appearance?
The skin around the bump is normal and hasn't changed in texture or appearance.
Final Diagnosis: Subungual Exostosis.
